newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares set high, seen up on Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares set high, seen up on Wednesday.

text.p: Polish shares set a new 30-month high on Tuesday and analysts said the higher turnover and strong post-price-fixing buying signalled a rise on Wednesday, with Warsaw gains linked with recent bourse rises abroad.

"I think the rise here is linked with the bull market on many bourses abroad, and now the fact that a high has been beaten helps," said Pawel Tarnowski, an analyst at Raiffeisen Capital and Investment.
But some analysts said the significant supply accompanying the stronger buying after price-fixing on Tuesday signalled only slight growth on Wednesday and a quick slowing of the uptrend.

The main market's all-share WIG index rose 1.2 percent to 14,993.0 and turnover rose 5.9 percent to 140.3 million zlotys ($50 million) on both markets. Gainers led losers by 51 to 13 with 14 stocks flat.

Analysts said the treasury's transfer of 32.9 percent of bank PBR shares to state-owned Powszechny Bank Kredytowy SA announced after the market closed could have a neutral-to- negative effect on PBR since many had hoped a foreign bank would get the stake.
Analysts were surprised by the scale of top-gainer electromagnetic transmitter maker Relpol's 9.8-percent jump in active trade.
Continuous trade turnover was at 2.2 million zlotys ($0.8 million) with biggest mover bank BIG up 2.4 percent.

Mass privatisation NFI units slipped 0.3 percent in 17.1-million-zloty ($6.1 million) continuous trade and were flat at 160 zlotys ($57) in the regular bourse session in a turnover of 30.1 million zlotys ($10.7 million).
Analysts said profit-taking on the units after their 11.9-percent surge since late September could result in their fall on Wednesday.
